metadata.titleEn: Albedo dataset in 1km-resolution in the Heihe River Basin (2001-2012)
metadata.description: The Global LAnd Surface Satellite albedo product was produced by using MODIS data product of 1km Surface reflectance (MOD/MYD09GA), Angular Bin inversion algorithm and statistics-based Temporal Filter algorithm based on statistical knowledge.This data set is in the GLASS global products using the two tiles covering the heihe river basin (h25v04, h25v05), after a Mosaic, projection transformation, and cutting the heihe river basin 1 km resolution epicontinental black empty albedo (black - sky albedo) and white empty albedo (white - sky albedo) data sets, including both Albers and UTM projection method, are raw format, space vector boundary of heihe river basin is the scope of the rectangle, temporal resolution for eight days.
metadata.instructions:
File name: raw data for grid storage, file folder to store by Albers and UTM projection, the file name "GLASS02A06. Albers1km. Ayyyyddd. Img", including yyyy representative years, DDD on behalf of the day, the file time resolution for eight days, such as GLASS02A06.Albers1km.A2001001.img, Represents the albedo data from the first day of 2001.
Data reading: it can be opened with Arcgis, Envi and other remote sensing software.

background: Land surface albedo is an important parameter to describe the radiant forcing in the climate system. A long-time series of global albedo products is needed to understand the mechanism of climate change. As the effects of global warming become more and more drastic, there comes an urgent demand to understand the global climate system as well as its influence on and reaction to environmental change or human activities. Land surface albedo is one of the major radiant forcing factors in the climate system because the albedo determines how much solar radiation will be absorbed at the land surface. Therefore, satellite remote sensing is the most effective technique to map the spatial and temporal distribution of the global land surface albedo. As a result of the advances in quantitative remote sensing research, many global or regional land surface albedo products have been released. The MODIS MCD43 series of BRDF (Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function) and albedo products, generated by NASAâ€™s MODLAND team, provide a global albedo map in a continuous time series from 2000 to the present. The MCD43 series of products are the most complete and widely recognized data-set for the global albedo, and their algorithm has a profound influence on other albedo inversion algorithms. Global change studies demand spatially complete and long-term global albedo products. To fill this gap, several international research projects have been devoted to the generation of long-term global albedo products by combining remote sensing data from different sensors/satellites.
research objective: Aiming to support global change and Earth system studies, GLASS (Global LAnd Surface Satellites) provides long-term global land surface albedo product from 1981 to 2010, which are generated from multisource remote sensing data and newly developed algorithms. It is critical to assess the quality of the GLASS product when it is released to the public. The work presented in this article provides the basic description of GLASS albedo product and gives a first-chance evaluation of its quality in the sense of integrity, robustness, and accuracy.
challenges: However, there are possible deficiencies in the current version of the GLASS albedo product, which come either from the algorithm or from the input remote sensing data. Although these algorithms are optimized in a statistical way, they certainly cannot account for all the situations of the complex real world. The a-priori database, which is critical in the STF algorithm, is derived from the MCD43B3 product; thus, this database inherits the limitations of the MCD43B3 product, such as insufficient samples in the tropical rain forest areas. The A VHRR data have limitations in the band number, calibration accuracy, and geometric processing accuracy. The evaluation work presented in this paper is also limited in data source as well as methodology.
methods: The blue-sky albedo of the GLASS product is calculated as a combination of BSA and WSA weighted by a sky light ratio factor, which is simply estimated as the function of the solar angle given in Long and Gaustad (2004). To check the consistency of the GLASS albedo product with the MCD43 product, we choose the GLASS02A06 product and MCD43B3 product which have exactly the same spatial coordinates and resolution, as well as similar temporal composition window.
dataset: Both the AB1 and AB2 algorithms are applied to retrieve the shortwave surface albedo from the MODIS data. The information source for the GLASS albedo product from 19 February 2000 to 31 December 2010 is the MODIS sensors onboard the Terra and Aqua satellites. The information source of the GLASS albedo product before 2000 is the A VHRR data. The FLUXNET network (Baldocchi et al. 2001) is currently the largest global data-set of energy and mass flux measurements at the ecosystem scale.
findings: The results show that the GLASS albedo product is a gapless, long-term continuous, and self-consistent data-set with an accuracy similar to that of the widely acknowledged MODIS MCD43 product.

Verification.Question: Is the GLASS albedo product reliant on algorithms that are optimized for statistical accuracy?
Does the GLASS albedo product use MODIS data from the Terra and Aqua satellites as an information source for data collected between 2000 and 2010?
Are there limitations in the GLASS albedo product due to insufficient samples in certain geographic regions such as tropical rainforests?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary sources of data for land surface albedo products?
Where are the potential deficiencies in the current version of a land surface albedo product typically found?
Concept Completion.Answer: Algorithm or input remote sensing data

Concept Completion.Question: When is the time range for the data collection of a global land surface albedo product using MODIS?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to generate long-term global land surface albedo products?
Example.Answer: The GLASS (Global LAnd Surface Satellites) product provides long-term global land surface albedo data from 1981 to 2010, generated from multisource remote sensing data and newly developed algorithms.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a challenge faced in the development of global albedo products and how they are addressed.
Example.Answer: One challenge in developing the GLASS albedo product is the limitations inherited from the MCD43B3 product, such as insufficient samples in tropical rain forest areas. These limitations stem from either the algorithm or the input remote sensing data.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset used to assess the quality of global albedo products?
Example.Answer: The FLUXNET network is currently the largest global dataset of energy and mass flux measurements at the ecosystem scale, which is used to evaluate the quality of global albedo products like GLASS.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the inherent challenges in developing long-term global albedo products using remote sensing data?
Feature Specification.Answer: algorithmic limitations, quality of input remote sensing data, insufficient samples in tropical rainforests

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining attributes of datasets derived from MODIS sensors for albedo measurements?
Feature Specification.Answer: global coverage, continuous time series from 2000 to the present, MCD43 series of BRDF and albedo products, consistent measure of global albedo

Quantification.Question: What is the time resolution of the land surface albedo dataset for the Heihe River Basin?
From what time period does the GLASS albedo product provide data using MODIS sensors?

Definition.Question: What does 'angular bin regression' mean in the context of albedo data collection methods?
Definition.Answer: Angular bin regression in the context of albedo data collection methods refers to a technique used for inverting algorithms to derive albedo from MODIS data, which takes into account the varying angles of sunlight and satellite view to accurately estimate surface reflectance.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'statistics-based temporal filter' in the production of land surface albedo datasets?
Definition.Answer: A statistics-based temporal filter is a data processing method used in the creation of land surface albedo datasets that utilizes statistical knowledge to smooth and refine the temporal sequence of data, enhancing the robustness and accuracy of the final albedo product.

Definition.Question: How is 'blue-sky albedo' defined in terms of its calculation for the GLASS product?
Definition.Answer: Blue-sky albedo is defined as a combination of black-sky albedo (BSA) and white-sky albedo (WSA) weighted by a sky light ratio factor, which is estimated based on the solar angle, as part of the calculation for the GLASS albedo product.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for the GLASS albedo product compare to those used for the MODIS MCD43 albedo product in terms of data source and temporal coverage?
Comparison.Answer: The GLASS albedo product is generated from multisource remote sensing data, including MODIS sensors onboard the Terra and Aqua satellites from 2000 to 2010 and AVHRR data before 2000. The MODIS MCD43 albedo product is derived solely from MODIS data. Both products provide long-term global albedo data, but the GLASS product combines data from different sensors to extend temporal coverage back to 1981.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in algorithmic approaches between the GLASS albedo product and other albedo inversion algorithms, particularly in handling data deficiencies?
Comparison.Answer: The GLASS albedo product employs a combination of angular bin regression and statistics-based temporal filter algorithms. Other albedo inversion algorithms may not incorporate these specific techniques. The GLASS product also faces potential deficiencies from algorithmic limitations and input data, similar to other products. It inherits limitations from the MCD43B3 product, such as insufficient samples in tropical rainforest areas, which are typical challenges in the field.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the evaluation approaches of the GLASS albedo product differ from those used in other global albedo datasets, especially regarding quality assessment metrics?
Comparison.Answer: The evaluation of the GLASS albedo product focuses on its integrity, robustness, and accuracy, providing a first-chance quality assessment in these areas. This is similar to other global albedo datasets, which also assess quality based on similar metrics. However, the GLASS evaluation is limited by data source and methodology, which may differ in scope and depth compared to evaluations of other datasets.

Interpretation.Question: How could the use of statistical optimization in algorithm development influence the reliability of land surface albedo measurements under varied environmental conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: Statistical optimization in algorithm development can enhance the reliability of land surface albedo measurements by improving data consistency and accuracy. However, it may not fully account for complex real-world conditions, potentially leading to deficiencies. This approach helps in managing some of the variability encountered in different environmental conditions but requires continuous evaluation and refinement to address its limitations.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the limitations of input remote sensing data, such as those from AVHRR, have on the spatial and temporal resolution of albedo datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: Limitations of input remote sensing data, like AVHRR, affect the spatial and temporal resolution of albedo datasets by introducing constraints in band number, calibration accuracy, and geometric processing. These limitations can impact the overall quality and applicability of the datasets, necessitating the use of advanced algorithms and additional data sources to enhance resolution and accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the potential deficiencies in the current albedo data collection algorithms, and how do these impact data accuracy?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The potential deficiencies in the current albedo data collection algorithms stem from either the algorithm itself or the input remote sensing data. Although these algorithms are optimized statistically, they cannot account for all real-world complexities. The a-priori database used in the STF algorithm, derived from the MCD43B3 product, inherits limitations such as insufficient samples in tropical rain forest areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the limitations of the AVHRR data used before 2000 for albedo product generation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations of the AVHRR data used before 2000 for albedo product generation include issues related to the band number, calibration accuracy, and geometric processing accuracy. These factors affect the quality and reliability of the data, which is critical for producing accurate and consistent albedo products.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the reliance on algorithms optimized in a statistical way affect the quality and limitations of albedo products?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The reliance on statistically optimized algorithms can lead to potential deficiencies in albedo products, as these algorithms may not account for all real-world complexities. This can result in limitations such as insufficient sample representation in certain areas, like tropical rainforests, and may affect the integrity, robustness, and accuracy of the albedo data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications for albedo product quality when using an a-priori database derived from another product, such as the MCD43B3?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using an a-priori database derived from another product like MCD43B3 can influence the quality of albedo products by inheriting the limitations of the source product. This can lead to challenges such as insufficient data samples in specific regions and may impact the overall accuracy and reliability of the albedo data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of generating a long-term global land surface albedo product using multisource remote sensing data and newly developed algorithms?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to support global change and Earth system studies by providing a reliable long-term global albedo product, which is critical for understanding the mechanisms of climate change and assessing the influence of environmental changes or human activities on the climate system.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can remote sensing data from different sensors or satellites be combined to generate a long-term global land surface albedo dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To generate a long-term global land surface albedo dataset, one approach is to combine remote sensing data from MODIS sensors onboard the Terra and Aqua satellites for data from 19 February 2000 to 31 December 2010 and A VHRR data for periods before 2000. This involves using newly developed algorithms to integrate these multisource data, ensuring the dataset is comprehensive and continuous.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in assessing the quality of a global land surface albedo product?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The quality assessment of a global land surface albedo product involves evaluating its integrity, robustness, and accuracy. This may include checking the consistency of the albedo product with existing recognized products, such as by comparing the GLASS albedo product with the MCD43 product using the same spatial coordinates, resolution, and similar temporal composition windows.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the challenges and procedural techniques for improving the statistical algorithms used in albedo inversion?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Improving the statistical algorithms used in albedo inversion involves addressing deficiencies that may arise from either the algorithm itself or the input remote sensing data. These procedures may include optimizing the algorithms to better account for complex real-world conditions, enhancing the a-priori database derived from products like MCD43B3 to address limitations such as insufficient samples in tropical rain forest areas, and improving the calibration accuracy and geometric processing of input data sources like the A VHRR.

Enablement.Question: What advancements in satellite remote sensing have enabled the production of global albedo products with high spatial and temporal resolution?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in satellite remote sensing, such as the development of the MODIS sensors onboard the Terra and Aqua satellites, have enabled the production of global albedo products with high spatial and temporal resolution. The MODIS MCD43 series of BRDF and albedo products provide a continuous time series of global albedo maps, which are crucial for understanding the spatial and temporal distribution of land surface albedo.

Enablement.Question: How do newly developed algorithms contribute to the generation of long-term global land surface albedo products?
Enablement.Answer: Newly developed algorithms, such as those used in the GLASS project, contribute to the generation of long-term global land surface albedo products by combining multisource remote sensing data. These algorithms are optimized statistically to account for a variety of real-world conditions, allowing for the creation of gapless, long-term continuous albedo datasets.

Enablement.Question: What challenges must be addressed to enhance the accuracy and completeness of land surface albedo datasets derived from remote sensing data?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges that must be addressed include potential deficiencies in current albedo products, which may arise from the limitations of input remote sensing data or the algorithms themselves. For instance, the a-priori database in certain algorithms inherits limitations such as insufficient samples in specific regions, and the AVHRR data used before 2000 have limitations in band number, calibration accuracy, and geometric processing accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in achieving complete global coverage with land surface albedo datasets?
Expectation.Answer: There are possible deficiencies in current albedo products due to limitations in input remote sensing data and algorithms which cannot account for all real-world complexities. The a-priori database is derived from products with limitations, such as insufficient samples in tropical rain forest areas, impacting dataset completeness.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in integrating multiple remote sensing data sources for long-term albedo datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include potential deficiencies from the input data's calibration accuracy, band number limitations, and geometric processing accuracy. These factors can affect the robustness and accuracy of the final albedo product.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to assess the quality of long-term global land surface albedo products?
Expectation.Answer: Assessing the quality of these products is essential to ensure integrity, robustness, and accuracy, which are crucial for supporting global change and Earth system studies. Potential deficiencies in algorithms or input data necessitate careful evaluation to maintain data reliability.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the limitations of using MODIS data for generating long-term global albedo products, and how could these limitations impact climate research?
Judgmental.Answer: MODIS data, while widely acknowledged for its accuracy, has certain limitations such as insufficient samples in tropical rainforest areas and limitations in band number, calibration accuracy, and geometric processing. These limitations could impact climate research by introducing biases or gaps in data, especially in regions with complex ecosystems, thus affecting the overall understanding of climate dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can ensure spatial completeness and continuity over long-term periods for global change studies.
Assertion.Answer: GLASS provides long-term global land surface albedo product from 1981 to 2010 by combining multisource remote sensing data and newly developed algorithms, ensuring spatial completeness and long-term coverage.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in using remote sensing data for generating accurate albedo products.
Assertion.Answer: Possible deficiencies in current albedo products may stem from the algorithm or input remote sensing data, with limitations such as insufficient samples in tropical rain forests and data source limitations.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how different algorithms are utilized to retrieve albedo data from satellite sensors.
Assertion.Answer: Both the AB1 and AB2 algorithms are applied to retrieve shortwave surface albedo from MODIS data, using information from MODIS sensors on Terra and Aqua satellites, with earlier data sourced from AVHRR.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used to generate global land surface albedo data from multisource remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methods involve using an Angular Bin regression inversion algorithm and a Statistics-based Temporal Filter algorithm to process MODIS 1km surface reflectance data products, resulting in the GLASS albedo products. The process includes data from various sensors, including MODIS and A VHRR, to ensure long-term and consistent albedo data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential challenges in developing a comprehensive albedo dataset using the existing algorithms and remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include potential deficiencies in the GLASS albedo product due to limitations in the algorithm and input remote sensing data. These include the inability to account for all real-world complexities, limitations inherited from the MCD43B3 product, and constraints related to band number, calibration accuracy, and geometric processing accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore how the consistency of different albedo products can be evaluated using standardized datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: The consistency between GLASS and MODIS albedo products can be evaluated by comparing the GLASS02A06 product and the MCD43B3 product, which share the same spatial coordinates, resolution, and similar temporal composition windows. This involves assessing the integrity, robustness, and accuracy of the datasets.
